Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Methods for Addressing Student Success in Totality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Implementation projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to design, implement, and assess strategies that can lead to comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The project at Grambling State University seeks to establish the foundation for building STEM student success, particularly for mathematics and physics students. The goal of the project is to prepare students for graduate school and careers.

Activities that are part of this project are: to redesign selected mathematics and physics courses by infusing problem-based learning; to support peer mentoring, mentoring and social integration of mathematics and physics undergraduate students; to develop interdisciplinary big data science courses; to infuse big data science concepts into existing chemistry courses; to provide professional development to faculty who will implement the new strategies; and to conduct an outreach program to high school students focusing on big data. The activities and strategies are evidence-based and what is learned through this project can serve as a model for other small liberal arts institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Grambling State University implemented the Collaborative Methods for Addressing Student Success in Totality (CMAST III) project with the intent to address the success of STEM majors by infusing engaging activities throughout their undergraduate experience. These engaging activities supported the project objectives which included 1) increasing the persistence of STEM majors by the addition of a Retention Program with emphasis on the sophomore year, 2) implementing a Big Data Training Program, and 3) enhancing the soft skills of STEM students. The strategy behind selecting the activities in each objective area emphasizes the Intellectual Merit of the CMAST III project which resolves that engagement throughout the curriculum and activities that connect students to STEM professions leads to the academic success of STEM students.

The Retention Program focused on improving the retention rates of 2nd to 3rd year STEM students. It consisted of scholarships, textbook awards, on-campus research, tutoring services for key gatekeeper sophomore courses, K-12 outreach, and travel to conferences. The Big Data Training Program sought to bring provide students with skillsets that would allow them more job opportunities upon completion of their undergraduate degree. The components of the Big Data Training Program included a summer camp as an outreach for 8th-12th graders, an interdisciplinary big data science course, a research component for students and faculty, faculty professional development, and infusion of big data into existing key courses across majors. Employers have noted that recent graduates lack basic soft skills that impact their productivity within the company. The Soft Skills Program was implemented to further develop the students’ need to adequately position them for greatness in their field. Trainings were provided in collaboration with the Office of Career Services on topics that included: Interpersonal/Communication Skills, Business and Table Etiquette, Problem Solving and Team Building, Why Professionalism is Important and What It Entails, the Elevator Pitch, Professional Wear, Interviewing Skills, Building Your Brand, and a Formal Dining Etiquette Training. In addition, the soft skills program provided a platform for students to practice presentation skills by presenting their research projects at monthly research meetings.

CMAST III was successful in implementing strategies that will decrease the gap in STEM workforce needs. Highlights of the program’s success are:

  • The interdisciplinary Introduction to Big Data course was implemented fall 2017 with majors enrolled from various areas that included accounting, business management, chemistry, computer science, computer information systems, economics, elementary education, engineering technology, psychology, and undecided.
  • Thirty-five (35) students in 8th-12th grade attended the Big Data Science Camp.
  • Forty-one (41) students and (15) faculty from all five STEM departments participated in the research program.
  • Big Data was infused into one existing course, BIOL 409: Biological Research. Big Data was also taught in a new course, CS 435: Big Data and Cloud Security, which was created and implemented into the curriculum fall 2018.
  • Approximately two-hundred and fifty (250) attendees received professional development through the Soft Skills Trainings.
  • Travel support was provided to faculty and students to attend more than 20 events that included conferences, annual meetings, competitions, outreach and team building activities.
  • STEM faculty and students presented research at technical conferences.  
  • Sixteen (16) scholarships were given. In addition, many STEM students received textbook awards.

The successes of CMAST III validates the Broader Impacts of this implementation project which is to create a model that can be used at the national level. This model addresses the enrollment, retention, and graduation of underrepresented groups in efforts to equip students with the necessary tools required to be successful in the STEM workforce. The materials developed thus far have been shared at various conferences such as the American Chemical Society (ACS) Conference, the HBCU-UP/CREST PI/PD Annual Meeting, the Louisiana Academy of Sciences, the National Society of Black Physicists Conference, the Emerging Researcher National Conference, and the IEEE Conference on Big Data Security. A chapter has been submitted for inclusion in the ACS’s book, Growing Diverse STEM Communities: Methodology, Impact, and Evidence. The CMAST PI, co-PIs, and project director co-wrote the book chapter entitled, “Design and Implementation of a STEM Student Success Program at Grambling State University” which is currently under review.
